page.title: 03Cottingham, a Central Place
page.content: One of the local people suggested to me that Cottingham was an older place than its larger neighbour Hull. Hull, she insisted, merely acted as the port for Cottingham's rich farming produce. It boasts to be the largest village in England still and does remain separate from Hull. For the geographer, it is a superb example of a{Central Place. There is little in its street pattern to hint at formal planning and yet it has all the services usually found in a small market town rather than a village. The{data count}shows shows over 70 shops and besides these it has a dozen or more service type shops which could not enter the data count. It has{council offices}and a library which lend higher status to the label{ {Central Place.} Saturday mornings on Hallgate busy with shoppers emphasize its extreme self-contained nature.
